Rule of threes, twisted proof

05 Nov 2019

Leer en Español

For this post, I want to explore a property of the natural numbers (or integers in this case) that is taught at a very young age and whose proof relies on a weird quirk of the decimal system.

The rule of threes

Assume that we have a very large number, like , and we want to know whether this number is divisible by 3, that is, than when we divide it by three, the remainder is 0:

An easy way of checking would be to just divide it and see, but, what if that was a lot harder? The rule of threes could help, it tells us that: a number is divisible by three if and only if the sum of its decimal digits is divisible by three. So we check:

Which is divisible by three! (We could keep going as )

With nine the same rule applies, but why does it work?

It is clear that the only possible remainders when dividing by three are 0, 1 and 2. We determine which one is the remainder of a number using Euclid’s Algorithm for division, also called Long Division, which gives us, for any integer :

Where is the number we find through division, and our remainder. The ring above, what it does, is “squash” every element in into its modular class, or, the remainder they give out when dividing by three, usually written with the bar, then would represent any number that gives a remainder of two when dividing by three.

This is what is called a “cyclic” ring, because it is clear that when you add , why? Because adding up numbers with a modulo of 2 (remainder of two) and numbers with a modulo of 1 always will give out a multiple of three.

This ring is closed and it has many more nice properties (because 3 is prime) but, why is this so interesting? Because we have a way to embed our numbers here, this is called the modulo operation and it has a very cumbersome notation:
